H0.text: Natural killer T cells are the cells that HIV infects, compromising the bodyâ€™s ability to protect itself from infection.

H1.text: Regulatory T cells are the cells that HIV infects; these cells coordinate the human immune response, and when they are killed or compromised, the body cannot effectively protect itself from infection.

H2.text: Cytotoxic T cells are the cells that HIV infects, and when these cells are killed or compromised, the body cannot effectively protect itself from infection.

H3.text: Helper T cells are the cells that HIV infects, the cells that coordinate the human immune response; when these cells are killed or compromised, the body cannot effectively protect itself from infection.

A4.text: HIV infects vital cells in the human immune system, such as helper T cells (specifically CD4+ T cells), macrophages, and dendritic cells.
